title: Restore Windows ARM64 emulation warning with proper detection
body:
This PR restores the emulation warning for Windows that was removed in #186008, but with proper detection logic to avoid the false positives that caused the original removal.

## Background

PR #186008 removed the Windows emulation warning because `app.runningUnderARM64Translation` was unreliable on Windows - it checked machine architecture instead of process architecture, leading to false positives.

## Changes

### 1. Windows Emulation Detection
Implemented proper Windows-specific detection in `nativeHostMainService.isRunningUnderARM64Translation()`:
- Uses `PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE` environment variable combined with `process.arch`
- Detects when an x64 VS Code process is running on ARM64 Windows (emulation scenario)
- Logic: `PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE === 'ARM64' && process.arch === 'x64'`
- Based on behavior patterns documented in VS Code's existing PowerShell detection code

### 2. Cross-Platform Warning Support
Updated the application startup flow in `app.ts`:
- Changed from macOS-only check to cross-platform detection
- Made `afterWindowOpen()` method async to properly await emulation detection
- Now shows warnings for both macOS (Rosetta) and Windows (x64 on ARM64) emulation

### 3. Windows Download URLs
Restored Windows-specific download URLs in the notification:
- Added back `win32arm64user` URLs for both stable and insiders builds
- Users now get correct download links for native Windows ARM64 builds

## Testing

The detection logic correctly handles different scenarios:
- ✅ x64 process on ARM64 Windows → Shows warning (emulation detected)
- ✅ ARM64 process on ARM64 Windows → No warning (native)  
- ✅ x64 process on x64 Windows → No warning (native)
- ✅ macOS Rosetta → Continues to work as before

This approach uses reliable Windows environment variables and avoids the false positives that necessitated the original removal, while providing users with the performance guidance they need when running emulated builds.

Fixes #258261.

title: String manipulation for editor custom labels

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-custom-labels
labels.description: Issues related to Workbench Editor Custom Labels

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In cases like having two main files in folders like
```
projects/very_long_folder_name/main.c
projects/other_very_long_folder_name/main.c
```
There should be a way to truncate the directory name in the `workbench.editor.customLabels.patterns` settings:
```
**/*.c : ${filename} - ${dirname}.slice(0, 4)...
```
So that the name of the files do not take up the entire space of the tab, but so that it is still possible to differentiate them. This also suggests adding other string manipulation macros.

Another macro that displays the directory name (or anything else) only when it is needed for having unique names in the tab, like the default `workbench.editor.labelFormat` does, would be helpful.

Merging `editor.customLabels` and `editor.label` would perhaps be best, so that the default/short/medium/long label displays would be defined by custom labels, as the default label formats of VScode.

title: Evaluation mechanism for Copilot Chat

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

**I would like a mechanism to evaluate prompts (or interactions in general) against an evaluation set with expected results**

VSCode Copilot Chat is becoming really powerful. It is now a good UX to interact with agent-based flows and supports many important pieces like MCP, prompts with limited tools, etc. The problem is that it becomes hard to systematically iterate on created flows. For instance, how could I improve a prompt that uses a few tools to work against many of the identified scenarios so I can provide to colleagues or other people in my organization knowing that it will work for the majority of cases?

I did an initial exploration of how this may look like [in this blogpost](https://www.bepuca.dev/posts/copilot-chat-eval/). The summary GIF of the flow I achieved:

![Demo showing the flow](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bepuca/copilot-chat-eval/refs/heads/main/demo.gif)

The problems I find with the current state are the following:
- I need to manually save each conversation, which could be solved by https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/254287
- Things must run sequentially, which does not scale, specially for long interactions. Solved if this feature request goes through: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/254473
- I need an external extension to do this
- I cannot save when the interaction is finished, I must ensure the save trigger waits enough (which is inefficient).
- It only supports 1-turn conversations. I think even with this constraint many powerful things can be achieved. In the future, maybe a mechanism to use the LM API to "simulate" users would also be interesting, but probably a story for another time.

At this stage, this is quite simplistic, as it does not work much for interactions with the workspace but I think it could still be quite powerful.

It is probably worth noting, that the thing required is only the engine to run in batch and save outputs. The metric calculation itself or exploration of results can be done through custom scripts, which is probably the right way anyway because it is really hard to generalize.

After digging a bit through the code, I found the concepts in `test/simulation`, and if I understand correctly, these tests are quite close to what would be useful to user creating their prompts, or iterating their instructions, etc. I was wondering if it would be possible to somehow expose the simulation functionality for users to create their own simulations to test their own prompts and workflows.

I think VSCode Copilot Chat now is getting really good at supporting agentic workflows, either using the workspace or not, but to create reliable flows to be used and iterated across teams, it would be awesome to have evaluation.

title: Close editors from picker (crtl + tab)

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-editors
labels.description: Managing of editor widgets in workbench window

labels.name: quick-open
labels.description: Quick-open issues (search, commands)

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Short cut to close tabs while picker is still open. Description: Right now the workflow is open picker "crtl + tab" select tab pushing enter, which closes the picker, than close the tab with "crtl + w". If you want to close other tabs that way you have to open the tab picker again. I know there is a close button that appears when hovering over a tab in quick selection. However there is no way to assign a shortcut to that close button which breaks the flow in my opinion when you have to move to the mouse just to hit that close button for a feature that you can only use with a shortcut to begin with.

title: Incorrect value of resource parameter is sent during authentication when two MCP servers have the same host

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19044

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open `.vscode\mcp.json` file in a workspace and add `product1` MCP server with the following URL - `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1`
2. Open `.vscode\mcp.json` file in a workspace and add `product2` MCP server with the following URL - `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product2`
3. Start `product1` MCP server.
4. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1` and receives a 401 response with `WWW-Authenticate` header with the following value - `Bearer resource_metadata="https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/mcp/product1"`
5. VS Code sends a GET request to `https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/mcp/product1` and receives protected resource metadata with `resource` field set to `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1`, `resource_name` field set to `Product1 MCP Server` and `authorization_servers` field set to an array with `https://api.acme.com` URL in it.
6. VS Code sends a GET request to `https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server` and receives OAuth authorization server metadata.
7. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/register` to dynamically register OAuth client.
8. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/authorize` to start authentication flow. `resource` query string parameter is added to request URL as required in [MCP authorization specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/authorization#resource-parameter-implementation). Value of `resource` parameter is `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1` as expected.
9. After authentication flow is finished, VS Code receives access code and can make authenticated requests to `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1` MCP Server.
10. Start `product2` MCP server.
11. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product2` and receives a 401 response with `WWW-Authenticate` header with the following value - `Bearer resource_metadata="https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/mcp/product2"`
12. VS Code sends a GET request to `https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/mcp/product2` and receives protected resource metadata with `resource` field set to `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product2`, `resource_name` field set to `Product2 MCP Server` and `authorization_servers` field set to an array with `https://api.acme.com` URL in it.
13. VS Code sends a GET request to `https://api.acme.com/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server` and receives OAuth authorization server metadata.

Actual result:
14. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/authorize` to start authentication flow. `resource` query string parameter is added to request URL as required in [MCP authorization specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/authorization#resource-parameter-implementation). But value of `resource` parameter is `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1`. Additionally, VS Code suggest to re-use existing authentication session for `Product1 MCP Server`. As a result, due to the wrong value of `resource` parameter, OAuth authorization server returns access token for `Product1 MCP Server` which cannot be used to access `Product2 MCP Server`.

Expected result:
14. VS Code sends a POST request to `https://api.acme.com/authorize` to start authentication flow. `resource` query string parameter is added to request URL as required in [MCP authorization specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/authorization#resource-parameter-implementation). Value of `resource` parameter is `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product2`. VS Code does not try to re-use existing authentication session for `Product1 MCP Server` to access `Product2 MCP Server`. Even though authentication is performed using the same OAuth authorization server, these two MCP servers have different resource identifiers and different access tokens.

Notes:
* This issue is reproduced only if two MCP servers with the same host are used at the same time. If either `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product1` or `https://api.acme.com/mcp/product2` is used, then MCP authorization flow works as expected, value of `resource` parameter sent in `https://api.acme.com/authorize` request is correct.
* Apparently, VS Code tracks authentication sessions per OAuth authorization server and not per MCP Server. When two MCP servers are used at the same time, the _Accounts_ pop up menu has only one `MCP (Product1 MCP Server)` or `MCP (Product2 MCP Server)` entry (the one which was started first is displayed in the list).

Type: Bug Hi, Most of the projects I work on, are located on a NAS. Sometimes I lose connection to it, and sometimes I just forget to connect. When this happens, VS Code won't open the project I last worked on, which I understand but it also 'forgets' the location of those projects in recent projects permanently. * added the `\n` softwrap check to `createLineBreaksFromPreviousLineBreaks()`, which handles word wrap while the editor is changing size (#258022)
* fixed wrapping in large files
  test https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/extensions/typescript-basics/syntaxes/TypeScript.tmLanguage.json (minify json first)
* Fixed wrapping sometimes not working correctly with `"editor.wordWrap": "bounded"/"wordWrapColumn"` (extending well past the 80char limit)
* extracted out the `lineText.includes('"')` check, so we don't have to recompute it on every single `\n`
* fixed wrapping when there was a escaped backslash before the `\n`
  `"\\\n"` now works

title: Fix leaked disposables when closing notebook inline chat
body:
Fixes #257872

## Problem

When using inline chat v2 in a notebook and clicking undo, disposables leak because async operations continue after the `ChatEditingModifiedNotebookEntry` is disposed. This results in the error:

```
Error: Trying to add a disposable to a DisposableStore that has already been disposed of. The added object will be leaked!
    at DisposableStore.add (lifecycle.js:344:30)
    at ChatEditingModifiedNotebookEntry._register (lifecycle.js:407:28)
    at ChatEditingModifiedNotebookEntry.resolveCellModel (chatEditingModifiedNotebookEntry.js:876:67)
```

## Root Cause

The `initializeModelsFromDiff()` method creates async cell model promises that can resolve after the main object has been disposed. When these promises resolve, they attempt to register new disposables via `this._register()` to an already-disposed store, causing the leak.

The sequence is:
1. User opens inline chat v2 in notebook and makes changes
2. User clicks undo, triggering disposal of `ChatEditingModifiedNotebookEntry`
3. Async promises from `resolveCellModel()` continue executing
4. When promises resolve, `getOrCreateModifiedTextFileEntryForCell()` tries to register disposables
5. This fails because the store is already disposed, but the objects still leak

## Solution

Added disposal checks before registering new disposables:

1. **`resolveCellModel`**: Check `this._store.isDisposed` before calling `this._register()`. If disposed, immediately dispose the reference to prevent leaks.

2. **`getOrCreateModifiedTextFileEntryForCell`**: Return `undefined` early if the store is disposed, preventing creation of new cell entries.

3. **Promise error handling**: Added catch blocks to gracefully handle cases where promises resolve after disposal.

The fix is minimal and surgical - it only adds disposal checks without modifying existing logic flow. The existing code already handles `undefined` returns from these methods with optional chaining and null checks.

## Testing

The fix prevents the disposable leak error while maintaining backward compatibility. The existing test suite includes `ensureNoDisposablesAreLeakedInTestSuite()` checks that will validate this fix.

title: Allow global copilot instruction files per project in a monorepo (i.e. one workspace, multiple projects)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, the only global instructions file that will be used in context with every message, and without having to provide it in the chatbox, is .github/copilot-instructions.md file. Otherwise, you use .github/instructions/*.instructions.md but must include it in the chat message. If I'm working in a workspace where the codebase has multiple projects (like in a monorepo), let's say, a React frontend under frontend/ and a Go(lang) backend, under backend/, can we have a global context for each? For example, if I'm working on the backend, I'd like a project specific instructions file to always be sent as context without having to include it in the chatbox. Otherwise, I have to include both frontend and backend information in the .github/copilot-instructions.md file, which seems inefficient, especially when working on just the backend for days. I'd rather keep one workspace for multiple projects rather than having a workspace for each.

title: June 2025 Recovery 3

labels.name: endgame-plan
labels.description: VS Code - Next release plan for endgame

body:
<!--
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!                                WARNING                                     !!
!!                                                                            !!
!! DO NOT COPY/PASTE THIS TEMPLATE TO CREATE AN ENDGAME PLAN MANUALLY.        !!
!! Instead, use https://tools.code.visualstudio.com/duties/endgame to create  !!
!! the endgame plan automatically.                                            !!
!! For more information check                                                 !!
!! https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Running-the-Endgame               !!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
-->

- [x] Create a milestone `June 2025 Recovery 3` **@alexr00**
- [x] Bump the version number & run `npm i` to bump `package-lock.json` as well. Ensure there are no other `package-lock.json` changes. **@alexr00**
- [x] [🔖candidate issues](https://github.com/issues?q=org%3Amicrosoft%20is%3Aissue%20milestone%3A%22June%202025%20Recovery%203%22%20label%3Acandidate)
- [x] Assign candidate issues to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] Review the `candidate` issues, and if they pass the review assign them to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] All `candidate` fixes are peer reviewed and pushed to `main` and then cherry-picked into the release branch **team**
- [x] Initiate `insiders` build from `main`
- [x] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [ ] Build and manually release Insider from main branch for vscode.dev (if there were vscode.dev candidates)
  - [ ] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [x] Build `stable` for all platforms from release branch **@alexr00**
- [x] Issues are verified on `stable` build and the `verified` label is added **@alexr00**
- [x] Check `https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/compare/release/<x.y>` to ensure no other commits have been made in the release branch **@alexr00**
- [x] The `insiders` build with all candidate fixes needs to be in the wild for 24 hours before recovery release, unless explicitly approved by @kieferrm
- [x] Update the release notes and include a link to a query for the fixed issues **@ntrogh**
- [x] [Sanity Testing](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Sanity-Check)
  - [x] Windows 64 bit ** @hediet  **
    - [x] System Installer
    - [x] User Installer
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI
  - [x] Windows ARM64 **@hediet **
    - [x] System Installer
    - [x] User Installer
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI
  - [x] macOS Intel ** @deepak1556  **
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Universal Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI
  - [x] macOS ARM64 ** @aiday-mar  **
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Universal Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI
  - [x] Linux x64 **@deepak1556 **
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] DEB
    - [x] RPM
    - [x] Snap
  - [x] Linux Server and CLI ** @alexr00  ** _(can be tested from any OS with Docker)_
    - [x] x64
    - [x] ARM32
    - [x] ARM64
    - [x] x64 Alpine
    - [x] ARM64 Alpine
- [x] Publish website **@rzhao271**
- [x] Publish stable build **@alexr00**
- [ ] (if there were vscode.dev candidates) Trigger the [vscode.dev Deploy pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/monacotools/Monaco/_build?definitionId=276) for `release/x.y` for the `prod` deployment target. **@alexr00**
  - [ ] Request approval from another team member at the necessary step to deploy the vscode.dev build. **@alexr00**
- [x] Create an official release **@alexr00**
  - [x] Create a tag (make sure you pull the release branch first): `git tag <x.y.z> release/<x.y>`
  - [x] Push the tag: `git push origin <x.y.z>`
  - [x] Create a GitHub release: [Open the GitHub tags](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/tags), and click far right `... > Create Release`. Use the correct title and description from our release notes. [Example](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.81.1)
- [x] Close the milestone on [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/milestones) **@alexr00**

title: `Delete Line` shortcut does not snap to cursor after deleting
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**/~~No~~

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: `Version: 1.102.2 (Universal) Commit: c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0`
- OS Version: `MacOS 15.5 (24F74)`

## Description
Using the `Delete Line` shortcut does not scroll the view back to the user's cursor, which would occur when using `Delete`, `Backspace` or making any other kind of text edit. Deleting a large chunk of text will generally leave the user in an essentially random location in the file, after all the text below the block being deleted has "moved up". The user has to then scroll up to find their place again.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a large file with several "view heights" of text
1. Select a large chunk of text, such that the beginning of the selection is off the top of the screen
1. Use the shortcut `Delete Line`
1. Observe that the view is left in the location it was before the delete, the cursor is way off the top of the screen

## Desired behaviour
After using the `Delete Line` shortcut, the view should snap back to the cursor's location i.e. it should produce the same outcome as if the user used `Delete Line` and then typed some characters into the text (which snaps the view).

title: Add allow/deny list dropdown for agent terminal commands (similar to MCP)
body:
## Summary

When GitHub Copilot or other coding agents run terminal commands, users currently need to manually manage allow/deny lists in settings. This creates friction in the workflow and requires users to context-switch to settings frequently.

## Feature Request

Add a dropdown or inline action when agents request to run terminal commands that allows users to:
- **Add to allow list** - automatically approve this command/pattern in the future
- **Add to deny list** - automatically deny this command/pattern in the future
- Similar to how Model Context Protocol (MCP) handles permissions

## Current Behavior

1. Agent requests to run a terminal command
2. User gets a permission prompt
3. User must manually navigate to settings to add commands to allow/deny lists
4. This breaks the flow and creates unnecessary friction

## Proposed Behavior

1. Agent requests to run a terminal command
2. User gets a permission prompt with options:
   - ✅ **Allow once**
   - ✅ **Allow and add to allow list**
   - ❌ **Deny once** 
   - ❌ **Deny and add to deny list**
3. User can make a one-click decision that persists for future similar commands

This would bring consistency with the MCP permission model and significantly improve the developer experience when working with coding agents.

title: Test: Context7 Integration for `#new` Project Scaffolding
body: Refs: #256739 - [x] macOS @lramos15 - [x] linux @karthiknadig - [x] windows @joshspicer Complexity: 4 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258369%0A%0A&assignees=bhavyaus) --- This update adds [Context7](https://context7.com/) support to the `#new` tool, enabling Copilot Chat to fetch up-to-date docs, best practices, and templates for project scaffolding. ## Prerequisites Enable Context7 Integration 1. Open the **VS Code Settings UI**. 2. Search for **"Context7"** and enable the setting: `GitHub › Copilot › Chat › New Workspace: Use Context7` 3. If you do not have this mcp server installed, use the link in the settings description to Install and start the Context7 MCP server ## Action 1. Run `#new` in an empty workspace to scaffold different types of projects. Refer to the sample prompts below for inspiration. 2. Verify the following: - **Tool Usage**: Context7 tools are used to fetch docs and scaffold info, with multiple calls for complex projects. - **Build Verification**: Dependencies install, the project builds successfully, and no errors occur. - **Setup & Docs**: README instructions work, config files are correct, and structure/dependencies follow best practices. - **Code Quality**: Code follows framework conventions, linting/tests work, TypeScript is correctly set up, and basic security practices are in place. - **Dependency Conflicts**: No incompatible versions from multiple tool calls. --- ## Sample Test Cases ### Next.js Project Creation - `#new Create a Next.js 14 project with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS` - `#new Build me a modern Next.js app with app router and server components` - `#new Set up a Next.js project with authentication using NextAuth.js` ### React Project Creation - `#new Create a React project with Vite and TypeScript` - `#new Set up a React app with React Router and state management` - `#new Build a React project with testing setup using Vitest` ### Express.js Backend Project - `#new Create an Express.js API with TypeScript and JWT authentication` - `#new Set up a Node.js backend with Express, MongoDB, and validation` - `#new Build a REST API with Express and OpenAPI documentation` ### Full-Stack Project - `#new Create a full-stack app with a Next.js frontend and Express backend for organizing local pet playdates`

title: Test: Manually provided client id and client secret flow
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252892

- [x] anyOS @ulugbekna
- [x] anyOS @bamurtaugh

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258367%0A%0A&assignees=TylerLeonhardt)

---

This iteration we have introduced a fallback mechanism for MCP servers that are using authorization servers that don't support Dynamic Client Registration.

Dynamic Client Registration allows the client (VS Code) to register with an authentication server and get back a client id (+maybe a client secret) which can be used to create a token that the MCP server can use. If you've used MCP auth yet for a non-GitHub, non-Microsoft server (like Paypal, Linear, etc) you've experienced this without realizing it.

Well, not all auth servers are cool like that. Spotify is an example of a server that doesn't have this. I believe okta is another. When an authorization server doesn't support this, we are suppose to provide a way for a user to give vscode a client id (+optionally a client secret) for it to use. It's a much more manual experience... and more of an "advanced experience" but this iteration we now support it.

Since I've got a simple Spotify MCP server already made, lets just use that for testing.

## Prereqs

### Get a Spotify client id

* Go here: https://developer.spotify.com/dashboard
* Login 
* Create app
* Now just leave this tab open in your browser for now

### Get the Spotify MCP running

#### Using the service Tyler stood up for you in Azure

~... If you are reading this, Azure won, and Tyler lost. You will have to run it manually.~ (Down to the wire at 6pm)

Your URL is `https://spotify-mcp-unofficial.azurewebsites.net/mcp`

### Manually starting the MCP server

If the above steps do not work

* Clone this: https://github.com/TylerLeonhardt/spotify-remote-mcp
* `npm i`
* `npm start`

Your URL is `http://localhost:{PORT}/mcp`

## Testing time

First add the MCP server to VS Code:
* Open the command palette
* `MCP: Add Server...`
* `HTTP`
* Use the URL from the pre-reqs

At this point, you should be taken through the flow that will involve you going back to the Spotify developer tab and filling out the form. Oh but `Which API/SDKs are you planning to use?` put `Web API` and `Web Playback SDK`.

The flow is a little bit funky, but keep in mind this is a fallback and is more advanced since it involves manual steps... so I think it's rare that this is really seen. Regardless, bugs are appreciated :)

If it all worked, you _should_ be able to say in chat "Play The Beatles on Spotify" and it should tool call its way to victory. Make sure you have an actual Spotify tab open somewhere or on your phone.

title: Test: MCP autostart behavior and trust
body:
- [x] anyOS @osortega
- [x] anyOS @hediet 

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258363%0A%0A&assignees=connor4312)

---

This iteration we added a currently on-by-default setting to autostart MCP servers, `chat.mcp.autostart`. We generally require each MCP server to be started once so we know what tools it provides, and these tool caches can be cleared with the command `MCP: Reset Tool Caches`. So, install some more MCP servers in your [user settings](https://code.visualstudio.com/insider/mcp) and workspace settings to test that:

- With the setting turned on, you don't see the blue refresh icon. Instead, the servers are started automatically when you submit a chat request. (Verify its state in `MCP: List Servers`)
- Chat should have access to the tools provided by new MCP servers in that first chat request. You can verify this either by asking a question that leads the model to use a tool, or checking that it's preset in the conversation log.
- Servers installed in the workspace should get a trust prompt initially when started _and_ whenever their configuration is changed. Specifically we should try to auto-start them if their config gets updated and trigger that trust prompt. Check that the various dialog options make sense. It should handle multiple servers prompting for trust in the same dialog. Cancelling out of the trust flow will allow the chat request to proceed without those servers.
- If trust is denied to one or more servers, they should not get prompted again, but a user should be able to start them manually either in `MCP: List Servers` or via the code lens in the mcp.json. Note that we don't trigger a trust prompt for the code lens as the user is already looking right at their config when actioning on those. Trust state is remembered based on the server name.
- If `chat.mcp.autostart` is set to `never`, servers should not autostart and the user should get the old behavior.

title: Test: virtual tools and limit behaviors
body:
- [x] anyOS @aiday-mar
- [x] anyOS @bamurtaugh 

Complexity: 5


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258360%0A%0A&assignees=connor4312)

---

This iteration we introduced a notion of 'virtual tools'. The virtual tools act as directories that only activate and show the tools they contain when the model calls them. If the tool count is over a threshold value, we'll group into these virutal tools. Grouping is done for an entire extension or MCP server if it presents a small number of tools, or with a categorization of tools when there are a large number. Built-in tools are never grouped.

This allows to avoid the infamous "128 tool limit" that folks hit, and at that limit we will now automatically generate virtual tools. Please test this:

1. Below 128 tools, everything should be normal. You should be able to call the model as usual.
2. [Install some more MCP servers](https://code.visualstudio.com/insider/mcp) to get more tools. Github and playwright have a large number and are good to test with.
3. Verify that, with >128 tools enabled, you see a small ⚠️  in the tool picker and on the tools button.
4. Your next chat request should have an "Optimizing tool selection" step. This may take a moment, but will be cached and you should not see it again unless you change your tool set. Note that you can also reset the cached groups via the `Developer: Reset Virtual Tool Groups` command (requires a window reload.)
5. Do some experimentation and verify that the model is able to still call tools correctly.
6. If you remove tools to go below the 128 limit, you should no longer see the warning.

title: Test: output polling for terminals and tasks, tools moved to core
body:
Refs #251653, https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257100

- [x] Windows @alexr00 
- [x] macOS @digitarald 
- [x] Linux @karthiknadig 

Complexity: 5

Authors: @meganrogge, @tyriar


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258358%0A%0A&assignees=meganrogge,tyriar)

---

The task and terminal tools were moved from the extension to core in this iteration. Please file an issue if you notice any unusual or incorrect behavior.

We’ve also added output polling for tasks and background terminals. This enables the agent to wait (up to 2 minutes) for processes to complete before proceeding.

After 20 seconds, you'll be prompted to either continue waiting or move on. Please test both options with both tasks and terminals:

If you choose to continue waiting, the agent will monitor the terminal until it becomes idle and then summarize the current state. If the terminal remains active, the agent will eventually report that the process is still running along with the latest output.

If you choose to stop waiting, the agent will provide a report of the current terminal or task state immediately.

Additional things to test with tasks:
- To test the create and run task tool, please delete your `tasks.json` file, kill any running tasks, clear the chat, and ask the agent to create and run a task for you. This should also trigger output polling and allow the agent to detect and potentially self-correct any errors.
- Also test running tasks that do not have a label.
- Test asking Copilot to get the output for a task

## Overview

This iteration I added initial support for render of math equations in chat responses. This is powered by katex. The feature is off by default by can be turned on by seeing: `"chat.math.enabled": true`

Math blocks are written with `$$...$$` while inline math is written using a single dollar sign `$...$`

4. Try changing the workbench theme. The equations should also be updated
5. Try creating some invalid equation such as, `echo this exactly: $#x$`. Confirm that it does not break rendering
6. Test math rendering in chat editors and quick chat

title: test: new implicit context flow
body:
Ref: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/251453

- [x] macOS @mrleemurray
- [x] linux @joshspicer
- [x] windows @roblourens

Complexity: 3


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258353%0A%0A&assignees=justschen)

---

This iteration, we've added a new implicit context flow that follows the following ideas:
1. selections are ALWAYS attached, no matter what mode or model, as long as there is a selection in the edotr
2. in ASK mode, the current file is always included implicitly. if you remove the implicit context widget, context will no longer be automatically attached.
3. in AGENT mode, the current file will NOT be included implictely. tool calls will suffice vs. adding context!

## Test Steps
1. In ask mode, try submitting some requests with implicit context.
2. Try adding files, removing files, and more (leaving this open ended on purpose to gather expectations)
3. When switching editors, note that the current implicit file will change.
4. In agent mode, try submitting some requests WITHOUT implicit context - note that it will still have context on which file you are in.
5. Try attaching context via selection!
6. Make sure that these contexts show up in the UI after submitted and are submitted with the request.

## Notes:
- a big thing regarding this item was expectations - if any part of the flow goes against your expectation, please let me know!

title: Copilot Chat in Edit Mode can respond as if it is able to access the terminal
body: It appears that references to tools Edit mode does not have access to (ie `terminal`) in the instructions can easily cause hallucinations that Edit mode does have access to these tools, reducing in observably lower quality responses and possible user confusion. Various versions of Claude and Gemini 2.0 Flash are affected. OpenAI models I tested appear unaffected. While providing agent-mode specific instructions like this [may not be documented](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/how-tos/configure-custom-instructions/add-repository-instructions), it appears to be a common practice since this sort of instruction has only recently begun to impact Edit and Ask mode results. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.28.5 - VS Code Version: 1.101.1 - OS Version: MacOS 15.5 (24F74) - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): edit mode - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4 - Logs: [GitHub Copilot Chat.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21477677/GitHub.Copilot.Chat.log) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Clone https://github.com/brandonemlaw/copilot-test or create a repo with similar [instructions](https://github.com/brandonemlaw/copilot-test/blob/main/.github/copilot-instructions.md) 2. Go to Edit mode in Copilot Chat Extension `0.28.5` in VS Code `1.101.1`. 3. Open the `readme.md` and ask Copilot Chat to `Help me add some more info to this file.` 4. Observe that Copilot Chat in Edit mode implies incorrectly it is running the script in the terminal. The chat is unaware the script does not exist, indicating it has not been run. Contrast with Agent mode which observes the script does not exist

title: Add jump buttons to test coverage quickpick for test navigation
body:
When viewing test coverage users can now quickly navigate to test classes directly from the coverage quickpick using new jump buttons.

## What's Changed

The test coverage quickpick now includes a "Go to Test" button (🡪 icon) next to each test item that allows immediate navigation to the test class location. This addresses the user workflow where developers want to quickly jump from coverage analysis to the actual test code.

### Before
```
Pick a test to show coverage for
> All tests
────────────────────────────────
  CodeUnit.cls
  Procedures.cls  
  TestComplexity.cls
  TestCoverageList.cls
```

### After
```
Pick a test to show coverage for
> All tests
────────────────────────────────
  CodeUnit.cls                    [→] (Go to Test)
  Procedures.cls                  [→] (Go to Test)
  TestComplexity.cls             [→] (Go to Test)
  TestCoverageList.cls           [→] (Go to Test)
```

## Implementation Details

- **Smart Navigation**: Uses a two-tier approach - first attempts direct navigation via test item URI/range, then falls back to `getCodeRelatedToTest()` API
- **UI Integration**: Leverages VS Code's standard `goToFile` icon and follows existing quickpick button patterns
- **Error Handling**: Gracefully handles navigation failures without disrupting the coverage workflow
- **Selective Display**: Buttons only appear on test items, not on the "All tests" option
- **Auto-close**: Quickpick automatically closes after successful navigation

## Technical Changes

- Enhanced `codeCoverageDecorations.ts` to support quickpick buttons via `IQuickInputButton` interface
- Added `IEditorService` integration for file navigation
- Implemented `onDidTriggerItemButton` handler with robust test location discovery
- Preserved all existing quickpick functionality (coverage preview, scroll position, filtering)

The implementation maintains full backward compatibility while adding this productivity enhancement for developers working with test coverage analysis.

Fixes #258327.

MCP, the run task, and run in terminal tools use a chat elicitation prompt to ask the user if they want to continue. 

Enable a screen reader and test the experience to ensure you're alerted when the prompt comes in, you can navigate the element using the keyboard, and you can open the accessible view and inspect the prompt there (`alt+f2`).

For example, you can ask the agent to run a long terminal command in a background terminal. After 20 seconds have passed, you'll receive a chat elicitation as a part of the response.

title: Claude Desktop MCP Configuration Conflict Breaks Github Copilot Chat

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

body: Type: Bug # GitHub Copilot - Claude Desktop MCP Configuration Conflict Bug Report ## 🐛 **Issue Summary** GitHub Copilot Chat (Ctrl+I) stops working when Claude Desktop has ANY MCP server configured ## 🚀 **Reproduction Script** Because VS Code automatically discovers MCP servers from Claude Desktop's configuration file and attempts to start them, creating a conflict that prevents Copilot Chat from functioning across ALL VS Code projects. **Confirmed Issue Timeline**: Weekend of July 26-27, 2025 on Windows 11 Enterprise system. ## 📋 **Bug Details** ### **Environment Information** - **OS**: Windows 11 Enterprise (Build 26100.1.amd64fre.ge_release.240331-1435) - **VS Code Version**: 1.102.2 (c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0, x64) - **GitHub Copilot Extension Version**: 1.346.0 - **GitHub Copilot Chat Extension Version**: 0.29.1 - **Azure GitHub Copilot Extension Version**: 1.0.58 - **Claude Desktop Version**: 0.12.55 - **User Profile**: [userprofile] - **Report Date**: July 28, 2025 (Issue occurred weekend of July 26-27, 2025) ### **Configuration Details** - **Claude Desktop Config**: `C:\Users\[userprofile]\AppData\Roaming\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json` - **MCP Server**: CIPP-MCP Proxy (FastMCP stdio-to-http bridge for Claude Desktop) - **Script Path**: `C:\Users\[userprofile]\1Repositories\CIPP-Project\CIPP-MCP\Proxy\cipp.local_mcp.py` ## 🎯 **Root Cause Analysis** **The core issue appears to be:** 1. **Claude Desktop configuration** defines MCP servers for Claude's use 2. **VS Code/GitHub Copilot automatically discovers** MCP servers from Claude's config file 3. **VS Code attempts to start** the MCP server (FastMCP based MCP Proxy) for its own use 4. **Backend MCP server is not running** because it was only intended for Claude Desktop 5. **Conflict occurs** when GitHub Copilot tries to use a partially functional MCP setup **Key observation**: VS Code shows the MCP server as "running" even when the backend service isn't available, and attempts to automatically restart the MCP process when stopped. Current behavior shows MCP icon in Copilot Chat endlessly "discovering tools" rather than complete failure. **Architecture Problem**: The FastMCP Proxy is designed as a stdio-to-http bridge for Claude Desktop, but VS Code treats it as a standalone MCP server, creating a broken state where: - Proxy process starts successfully (appears "running" to VS Code) - Backend MCP endpoint is not running - Proxy cannot fulfill MCP requests, causing Copilot Chat to malfunction or enter infinite discovery loop - **VS Code automatically restarts the proxy** when manually stopped, creating persistent conflict ## 🔄 **Reproduction Steps** ### **Prerequisites** 1. Install VS Code with GitHub Copilot extension 2. Install Claude Desktop application 3. Have a MCP server configured for Claude Desktop **Note**: The specific MCP server doesn't matter - ANY MCP configuration in Claude Desktop triggers this conflict but it is especially apparent if the MCP server is not functioning or in development. ### **Exact Configuration That Caused the Issue** The problematic Claude Desktop configuration that causes the endless discovering tools loop is below. Another variation breaks copilot chat completely: ```json { "mcpServers": { "CIPP-MCP Proxy": { "command": "python", "args": ["C:\\Users\\[userprofile]\\1Repositories\\CIPP-Project\\CIPP-MCP\\Proxy\\cipp.local_mcp.py"], "env": { "PYTHONPATH": "C:\\Users\\[userprofile]\\1Repositories\\CIPP-Project\\CIPP-MCP\\Proxy" } } } } ``` **Note**: The original problematic configuration may have used a `run` command instead of `command`/`args`. This one prevented copilot chat from responding at all. That chat interface was available but it would simply ignore any converstatons. As soon as I would stop the CIPP-MCP copilot chat would immediately respond to whatever I asked it last and keep working for a few minutes until VS Code restarted CIPP-MCP. The current configuration still causes MCP discovery issues in VS Code, demonstrating that any Claude Desktop MCP configuration triggers the conflict. ### **Steps to Reproduce** 1. **Verify Copilot Working**: Open VS Code, test GitHub Copilot chat (Ctrl+I) and inline suggestions 2. **Add Claude Desktop MCP Config**: Edit the config file above with the problematic configuration 4. **Test Copilot**: Return to VS Code and observe Copilot Chat malfunction ### **Expected Behavior** - GitHub Copilot should ignore Claude Desktop MCP configurations or have the ability to toggle them on/off - VS Code should not attempt to start MCP servers from Claude Desktop's config unless explitly requested by the user - Both tools should operate independently without cross-contamination of configurations ### **Actual Behavior** *(Confirmed on July 26-27, 2025)* - VS Code/GitHub Copilot discovers MCP server from Claude Desktop config immediately upon VS Code startup - **Current behavior**: MCP icon appears in Copilot Chat but shows "discovering tools" indefinitely - **Previous severe behavior**: GitHub Copilot Chat would accept input but would not respond at all until I 'stopped' CIPP-MCP Proxy from VS Code - **Configuration dependency**: Removing Claude Desktop config immediately restores Copilot functionality - **Restart cycle**: Restoring the config breaks Copilot again, confirming direct correlation - **Automatic restart issue**: Even when manually stopping the CIPP-MCP Proxy process, VS Code automatically restarts it within minutes - **Persistent conflict**: VS Code continues attempting to manage the MCP server, creating an ongoing conflict state - The conflict persists until Claude Desktop config is completely removed ## 🔍 **Diagnostic Information** ### **Files to Check During Reproduction** - `C:\Users\[userprofile]\AppData\Roaming\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json` (Claude config) - VS Code settings: `%APPDATA%\Code\User\settings.json` - VS Code extension logs: `%APPDATA%\Code\logs\` - GitHub Copilot extension logs: Check VS Code Developer Tools > Console - Windows Event Viewer: Application and System logs for any MCP or Python process errors - Task Manager: Check for python.exe processes related to Claude MCP servers/proxies ### **Potential Conflict Areas** 1. **Configuration Cross-Contamination**: VS Code reading Claude Desktop's MCP config 2. **Process Management**: VS Code trying to manage MCP servers intended for Claude 3. **Architecture Mismatch**: FastMCP Proxy designed for Claude's stdio ↔ HTTP bridge, not direct VS Code usage 4. **Resource Conflicts**: Proxy processes started without proper backend connections (real MCP server unavailable) 5. **Automatic Restart Logic**: VS Code persistently restarts stopped MCP processes, preventing manual resolution 6. **State Management**: Partial MCP initialization causing Copilot to enter infinite discovery loops 7. **IPC/Communication**: Interference between Copilot and improperly initialized MCP servers ## 🔍 **CIPP MCP Proxy Code** *(The Python script VS Code incorrectly tries to execute)* The proxy script that VS Code attempts to start is a FastMCP bridge designed only for Claude Desktop: ```python from fastmcp import FastMCP # Create a proxy directly from a config dictionary config = { "mcpServers": { "default": { # For single server configs, 'default' is commonly used "url": "http://localhost:3001/mcp", "transport": "streamable-http" } } } # Create a proxy to the configured server proxy = FastMCP.as_proxy(config, name="CIPP-MCP Proxy") # Run the proxy with stdio transport for local access if __name__ == "__main__": proxy.run() ``` **Architecture Issue**: This proxy is designed to: 1. Accept stdio input from Claude Desktop 2. Bridge to a streamable-http MCP server at `http://localhost:3001/mcp` or the real MCP endpoint 3. The backend MCP server (`localhost:3001`) is NOT running when VS Code starts the proxy 4. This creates a "zombie" proxy process that VS Code shows as "running" but is non-functional ## 📊 **Impact Assessment** ### **Severity**: High - **Reason**: Completely breaks GitHub Copilot functionality - **Workaround**: Remove Claude Desktop MCP configuration ### **User Impact** *(Real-World Impact)* - Developers cannot use both GitHub Copilot and Claude Desktop with MCP servers simultaneously - Forces choice between AI tools instead of allowing complementary usage - Significant impact on development productivity, especially for users relying on Copilot Chat - Issue occurs silently - users may not realize Claude Desktop MCP config is the cause - Affects enterprise users who may have both tools configured for different purposes ## 🔧 **Workaround** **Only complete removal of Claude Desktop MCP configuration provides permanent resolution:** 1. Edit `C:\Users\[userprofile]\AppData\Roaming\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json` 2. Remove the `mcpServers` section entirely or set to `{}` 3. Restart Claude Desktop application **Note**: Manual process termination is insufficient - VS Code automatically restarts the MCP process within minutes. ## 🎯 **Expected Resolution** - GitHub Copilot should work independently of Claude Desktop MCP configuration - Both tools should be able to coexist without interference - No configuration conflicts should occur between separate AI tools VS Code version: Code 1.102.2 (c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0, 2025-07-22T12:15:48.520Z) OS version: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26100 Modes:
